description: From Middle English sonnebeem, sonne beem, from Old English sunnbēam, sunnebēam (“sunbeam”), equivalent to sun +‎ beam.

entries.meaning: A visible, narrow, and intense (relative to ambient light) ray of sunlight.
examples: I cut-in various other material to this; for instance, a shot of a rushing brook in springtime, with dancing sunbeams reflected in the water; of birds splashing in the village pond; and, finally, of a laughing child.

entries.meaning: (Australia, colloquial, dated) An item of cutlery or crockery laid out on a table, but not used, and which can be returned to the drawer without being washed.
Any of various lycaenid butterflies of the genus Curetis.
Any hummingbird of the genus Aglaeactis.
(UK) Synonym of sunshine (“ironic form of address to an inferior or troublemaker”)
examples: DOCTOR: You seem to be our best bet so far, don't you think so, Mel? Mel? Where's Mel?DEPUTY: No, no, no, sunbeam. You're coming with us.
